item.title: A Welsh Village Embraces Its Bond With the Queen
item.description: A disaster at Aberfan, a small Welsh community, almost 60 years ago forged an unusual link between the community and the queen. The atmosphere there today — quiet grief coupled with brief flashes of dissent — encapsulates the national mood.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Mary Turner
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Moy Road in Aberfan, the site of a school and several houses that were destroyed during an avalanche that killed 116 children and 28 adults in a disaster in October 1966.

item.title: Meghan Markle and Prince Harry’s U.K. Trip Under Scrutiny
item.description: The actions of Meghan, and her husband, Prince Harry, as they mourn the queen have been the subject of biting social commentary — as usual.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, with Prince Harry, her husband, behind Prince William and Catherine, the Princess of Wales, viewing flowers last Saturday that were left for Queen Elizabeth II.

item.title: Russia Advances on Key City in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: Recent setbacks haven’t deterred Russian forces from advancing on the city of Bakhmut, which is critical to claiming all of the Donbas region. In the south, power was restored to the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian emergency services worker collecting unexploded ordnance from the side of a road near Izium on Saturday.

item.title: In South Korea, President Yoon Treads Fine Line Between U.S. and China
item.description: Yoon Suk-yeol has aligned his country more closely with the United States, but there are limits to how far he can go without angering China or provoking North Korea.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Yoon Suk-yeol of South Korea

item.title: Powerful Typhoon Thrashes Japan, With Millions Told to Evacuate
item.description: The storm, called Nanmadol, carried gales and heavy rain as it was expected to creep up nearly the entire length of the country.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: A car passing a damaged tree as Nanmadol approached in Izumi on the southwestern island of Kyushu on Sunday.

item.title: Strong Earthquake Strikes Taiwan
item.description: A southeastern county was shaken by a powerful temblor for the second day in a row, and the authorities were working to assess damage.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: USGS map of 6.9-magnitude earthquake in Taiwan on September 18, 2022.

item.title: Ukraine’s Donbas, Where Putin Sowed the Seeds of War
item.description: In one small town in the Donbas region, everything suddenly fell apart. It was part of Vladimir Putin’s grand plan, and it helped lay the groundwork for the invasion of Ukraine. Now things are heating up again.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A road outside Chasiv Yar with mountains of slag visible on the horizon.

item.title: Nancy Pelosi Visits Armenia Amid Conflict With Azerbaijan
item.description: The House speaker, who has previously inserted herself at the center of global conflicts, is the highest-ranking American official to visit Armenia since it gained independence 30 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: In a photo provided by the Armenian government, Speaker Nancy Pelosi was greeted by Alen Simonyan, the president of the National Assembly, on Saturday outside Yerevan, Armenia’s capital.

item.title: Prince William and Prince Harry Stood Vigil Over the Queen at Westminster Hall
item.description: Prince William and Prince Harry stood vigil over their grandmother, Queen Elizabeth II, at Westminster Hall as mourners streamed in to pay their respects.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: The line to see Queen Elizabeth II lying in state at Westminster Hall stretched for miles along the south bank of the Thames on Saturday in London.

item.title: What’s Behind the Success of the Far-Right Sweden Democrats?
item.description: Campaigning on issues like immigration, religion, crime and the cost of environmental rules, the Sweden Democrats, a party with neo-Nazi roots, built its support.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Christina Anderson
item.media:description: A campaign poster for the Sweden Democrats with the slogan “Sweden Will Be Great Again” on a bus stop in Stockholm last month.

item.title: The U.S. Vowed to Defend Central American Democracy. Autocrats Had Other Plans.
item.description: The Biden administration’s plan to stem migration by building the rule of law in Central America has thus far failed to stop authoritarians or persuade people to stay.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Jody García
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris with President Alejandro Giammattei of Guatemala last year in Guatemala City.

item.title: After 75 Years, Cheetahs Return to India in a Grand Experiment
item.description: Scientists aim to determine whether a predator population can be restored in a place where it was hunted into extinction.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: A cheetah and her two grown cubs in Namibia at a Cheetah Conservation Fund enclosure. The organization is a main partner in the relocation of eight cheetahs to India this weekend.

item.title: In Hong Kong, Mourning the Queen and the Past
item.description: A memorial for Elizabeth has given residents of the former British colony a rare platform for public, if quiet, political dissent.
item.dc:creator: Zixu Wang and John Yoon
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Waiting to pay tribute to Queen Elizabeth II outside the British Consulate General in Hong Kong on Friday.

item.title: Desperate Clients Hold Up Lebanese Banks to Get Their Own Cash
item.description: The holdups are becoming increasingly common, with five on Friday alone as a financial crisis and a freeze on bank withdrawals push some depositors to the brink.
item.dc:creator: Hwaida Saad and Jane Arraf

item.title: How Russian Trolls Helped Keep the Women’s March Out of Lock Step
item.description: As American feminists came together in 2017 to protest Donald Trump, Russia’s disinformation machine set about deepening the divides among them.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry

item.title: Biden Warns Russia Against Using Unconventional Weapons
item.description: Some officials worry that the more cornered Vladimir Putin feels, particularly with recent setbacks from Ukraine’s counteroffensive, the greater the chance that he might turn to an unconventional weapon.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Norimitsu Onishi
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian emergency services workers collecting unexploded ordnance from the side of the road near Izium on Saturday.

item.title: Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant Has Power Restored, Watchdog Says
item.description: Maintaining power at Europe’s largest nuclear plant has been crucial to prevent a meltdown in the shadow of fighting nearby.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel
item.media:description: A motorcade transporting experts with the International Atomic Energy Agency arrived at the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant outside the Russian-controlled city of Enerhodar, Ukraine.

item.title: Three Ancient Sculptures Will Be Returned to Italy
item.description: Three statues were returned to Italy after the J. Paul Getty Museum discovered they had been looted. They will be displayed temporarily in Rome before heading to Taranto, Italy, their permanent home.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Emanuele Antonio Minerva and Agnese Sbaffi/Italian Ministry of Culture
item.media:description: Orpheus and the Sirens

item.title: What Does Queen Elizabeth’s Death Mean for Canada?
item.description: The accession of King Charles III may inspire more discussion about the relevance of the monarchy in Canada, but materially, experts say it’s business as usual.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: King Charles III accompanied the procession taking Queen Elizabeth II’s coffin to Westminster Hall.

item.title: Baking Challah
item.description: Summer’s rituals are giving way to fall’s, but for the moment, you can enjoy them all.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Japan Warns ‘Violent Typhoon’ Nanmadol Could Hit on Sunday
item.description: The storm, called Nanmadol, carried gales and heavy rain as it crept up nearly the entire length of the country.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: A car passing a damaged tree as Nanmadol approached in Izumi on the southwestern island of Kyushu on Sunday.

item.title: An eastern city under attack wonders how far Ukraine’s offensive can go.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

item.title: Mass Graves in Izium Renew Focus on Holding Russia Accountable
item.description: The U.N. General Assembly voted to allow Ukraine’s president to address the gathering of world leaders with a recorded message next week.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Edward Wong
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A city block in Izium on Wednesday. Civilian infrastructure in Ukraine has been damaged throughout the war, with Ukrainian officials claiming the Russian military has targeted it purposefully.

item.title: Woman’s Death in Iran After Arrest by the Morality Police Triggers Outrage
item.description: Mahsa Amini was detained for allegedly violating dress rules. Her suspicious death, publicized by social media, has led to protests and condemnations by prominent Iranians.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: An undated picture of Mahsa Amini, provided to Iran Wire by her family.

item.title: At Mass Grave Site in Ukraine’s Northeast, a Sign of Occupation’s Toll
item.description: Russian troops held the city of Izium, in northeastern Ukraine, for six months. One burial site found this week could hold the remains of more than 400 people, investigators said.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Marc Santora
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian investigators at a large grave site in the forest by Izium, in northeastern Ukraine. Russian soldiers occupied the city for six months, before fleeing last week.

item.title: Biden Meets With Relatives of Brittney Griner and Paul Whelan
item.description: The president is trying to negotiate the release of the two Americans imprisoned in Russia amid poisoned relations over the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Aishvarya Kavi
item.media:description: Brittney Griner, a W.N.B.A. star, in a court building outside Moscow in August. She has been held in Russia since mid-February.

item.title: Putin Threatens to Escalate War as India Distances Itself From Russia
item.description: After India’s prime minister said that now is not the time for war, an increasingly isolated Mr. Putin threatened “more serious” actions in Ukraine while insisting he was ready for talks.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Mujib Mashal and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India, who met President Vladimir V. Putin on Friday, told the Russian president that “today’s era is not of war.”

item.title: Haiti’s Fuel Price Hike Escalates Its Worst Protests in Years
item.description: Discontent over economic misery spilled into the largest national protests in years, prompting international calls for action.
item.dc:creator: Milo Milfort, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Andre Paultre
item.media:description: Protesters erected burning barricades in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, on Thursday, as the country was racked by widespread protests.

item.title: U.S. Immigration Debate Rings Hollow in Venezuela as Migrants Flee
item.description: More than a fifth of Venezuela’s population has fled the country, and critics said the move by Republican governors to ship migrants to other states would not dissuade others from leaving.
item.dc:creator: Sheyla Urdaneta, Julie Turkewitz and Isayen Herrera
item.media:credit: Matt Cosby for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants boarding buses at a ferry terminal on Martha’s Vineyard on Friday. The migrant were flown there by Gov. Ron DeSantis, a Republican from Florida.

item.title: Ukraine is consolidating its gains, but Russia is shoring up its defensive lines, a Pentagon spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian tanks and military vehicles in Balakliya, in northeastern Ukraine, after the town was liberated from Russian control.

item.title: King Charles Faces Challenges but Is Off to a Stirring Start
item.description: King Charles III has had an enthusiastic public reception so far, but for this man of strong opinions, replacing the beloved queen will be a challenge.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: King Charles III and his siblings standing vigil beside the coffin of their mother, Queen Elizabeth II, as it lies in state on the catafalque in Westminster Hall on Friday.

item.title: Russia and Ukraine trade blows in the south.
item.dc:creator: Oleksandr Chubko
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian artillery firing from a position in the Kherson region earlier this month.

item.title: Video Reveals How Russian Mercenaries Recruit Inmates for Ukraine War
item.description: In a video posted on social media on Tuesday, the de facto leader of a Russian mercenary group explained to Russian convicts how they could earn their freedom by fighting in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert

item.title: What Ibrahim al-Nabulsi’s Killing Reveals About the West Bank
item.description: The life of Ibrahim al-Nabulsi, the son of a Palestinian security official, reflects some of the dynamics at play as leaders jockey to succeed Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian Authority president.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Palestinians surrounded the body of Ibrahim al-Nabulsi, who was killed in a raid by the Israeli military, during his funeral in the West Bank town of Nablus last month.

item.title: Prince William Moves Into the Spotlight as Heir to the Throne
item.description: Many royal watchers and historians are looking to William and his wife, Catherine, who rank high in popularity polls, as the long-term future of the British monarchy.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Prince William in Scotland in May. He has lived a life largely devoid of the controversy, and occasional scandals, that have engulfed his relatives.

item.title: India’s Leader Tells Putin That Today Is No Time for War
item.description: Mr. Modi was speaking on the s
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia met on Friday in Samarkand, Uzbekistan, as seen in a photo provided by Russian state media.

item.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader Cancels Public Appearances After Falling Ill
item.description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei is on bed rest and under observation by a team of doctors, according to four people familiar with his health situation.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Khamenei.Ir, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: In a photo made available by his office in June, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei was pictured at a ceremony in Tehran.

item.title: The ‘Queue’ to View Queen Elizabeth’s Coffin Closes Temporarily
item.description: Would-be mourners in line to pay their respects — known as the Queue — will probably have to wait 24 hours, the British government said, after it reached capacity on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The line along the Thames on Thursday. The estimated wait time for people joining it on Friday evening was 24 hours.

item.title: Floods in Central Italy Leave at Least 9 Dead
item.description: The downpour was the latest in a summer of extreme weather events. Streets were turned into rivers, bridges and highways were blocked and thousands were left without power.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Flash flooding on the Sanguerone River in Sassoferrato, central Italy, on Friday.

item.title: Profiting in Congress
item.description: Dozens of lawmakers trade stocks related to their work, and it’s harming trust in the government.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of Congress can buy and sell stocks with few restrictions.

item.title: In Central Asia’s ‘Great Game,’ China Seeks the Advantage
item.description: Xi Jinping’s visit to Central Asia this week sheds a light on his country’s efforts to increase its sway in the vast, resource-rich region once considered Russia’s domain.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Kazakhstan Presidential Press Office, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, arriving in Kazakhstan on Wednesday as part of his first trip outside China since the pandemic started.

item.title: At Old Coal Mines, the American Chestnut Tries for a Comeback
item.description: Across Appalachia, scientists and foresters are trying to reintroduce a hybrid version, helping to revive damaged land while also bringing back a beloved tree.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao and Maddie McGarvey

item.title: Ukrainian prosecutors work to document evidence of war crimes in Kharkiv.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Securing the area with the unidentified graves of civilians and Ukrainian soldiers in Izium on Thursday.

item.title: ‘At the Breaking Point’: Tibetans, Under Lockdown, Make Rare Cries for Help
item.description: China’s ever-tightening Covid rules have prompted public complaints from residents of areas usually intimidated into keeping quiet.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Visual China Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A socially distanced line, background, of people waiting for Covid tests in Lhasa, the capital of Tibet.

item.title: A mass grave site is found in recently reclaimed Izium.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Marc Santora
item.media:description: Crosses at a burial site in a forest on the outskirts of Izium, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Cultural Cringe and ‘The Lost City of Melbourne’
item.description: A new documentary goes some way to explaining why the city looks the way it does.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A view of the city square in Melbourne in 1970.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: A meeting between Vladimir Putin and Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Russian President Vladimir Putin, left, listens as Chinese President Xi Jinping makes remarks at their meeting Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Will Send $600 Million in Military Supplies to Ukraine
item.description: The new shipment continues the Pentagon’s recent trend of sending ammunition that Ukraine needs to carry out heavy fighting in the country’s south, east and northeast.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A multiple rocket-launching vehicle being transported by a Ukrainian military vehicle in June.

item.title: Putin Nods to Xi’s ‘Concerns’ on Ukraine War
item.description: The discordant messages of China’s president, Xi Jinping, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia suggested that despite an earlier pledge of “friendship,” Moscow does not have an unconditional ally in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: In a photograph released by Russian state media, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and President Xi Jinping of China meeting in Uzbekistan, on Thursday.

item.title: In ‘Cancer Alley,’ Judge Blocks Huge Petrochemical Plant
item.description: The company, an affiliate of Formosa Plastics, said it intended to move forward with the $9.4 billion complex in St. James Parish despite the ruling.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: An oil refinery in Reserve, La. Reserve is in St. John the Baptist Parish, which abuts St. James Parish in “Cancer Alley,” where the plastics plant would have been built.

item.title: Putin’s admission of Chinese concerns about Ukraine isn’t a sign of a weakening bond, U.S. officials said.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Edward Wong
item.media:description: In this combination of pictures, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, meeting with Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, in Uzbekistan at a summit on Thursday.

item.title: The E.U.’s top official meets with Zelensky.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, met with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Kyiv on Thursday.

item.title: Pope Francis: Arming Ukraine Can Be ‘Morally Acceptable'
item.description: The pontiff said that it is acceptable for countries to provide weapons to Ukraine so that the country can defend itself, but stressed that communication channels with Russia should remain open.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis spoke to reporters after attending an interfaith conference in Kazakhstan this week.

item.title: Biden to Meet With Families of Griner and Paul Whelan
item.description: The fates of both Americans have been complicated by the deteriorating diplomatic relationship between the United States and Russia over President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: The Putin-Xi Summit
item.description: Plus Europe’s tilt to the right continues, and Roger Federer is retiring.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia meeting with China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, on the sidelines of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization summit in Samarkand, Uzbekistan, on Thursday.

item.title: A mass grave site with 440 bodies was found in Izium, a police official said.
item.dc:creator: William Lamb
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier in Izium, in northeastern Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Princess Anne’s Influence, and Workload, Rises in a Slimmed-Down Royal Family
item.description: Often appearing at more than 400 events a year, Anne is likely to become even more central as a trusted adviser to her brother, the king.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Princess Anne at Balmoral Castle, in Scotland, on Saturday.

item.title: Rise of Far-Right Party in Sweden Was Both Expected and Shocking
item.description: The Sweden Democrats, with roots in neo-Nazism, came in second in national elections and will have a powerful influence on a new center-right government.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Christina Anderson
item.media:credit: Stefan Jerrevång/TT News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: “If we are going to support a government that we’re not sitting in, it’s going to cost,” Jimmie Akesson, leader of the Sweden Democrats, said before the election on Sunday.

item.title: A Detailed Rundown of Queen Elizabeth’s Funeral Day
item.description: On Monday, dignitaries from across the globe will bid farewell to the queen at a service in Westminster Abbey.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II has been lying in state at Westminster Hall since Wednesday afternoon.
